projects.title: Project Coordination Sustainable Port Development in an African Context
projects.description:
The aim of this project is to develop a framework and tools for designing integrated and sustainable ports in Africa in which environmental, economic and public benefits are balanced. We want you to get connected!

The project incorporates an integrated approach to port design that is stakeholder-inclusive and encompasses engineering, ecological, economic and governance aspects. A bottom-up approach is employed, whereby research in all four disciplines is directed at relevant and practical cases in Africa. Academia, applied research and knowledge institutes, practitioners and potential users collaborate as partners in this project; this is invaluable for ‘action-based’ research and ‘demand driven’ knowledge development. 

Additional deliverables of the project are ‘Best practice guidelines for implementing integrated and sustainable port development in Africa’ and an international 'Green ports Africa network', a community of researchers and private sector practitioners.

Partners: Technical University Delft (TuDelft), Wageningen University (WUR), IMARES, University of Ghana, UNESCO-IHE, Netherlands-African Business Council (NABC), Boskalis, Deltares, Ghana Netherlands Business and Culture Council (GNBCC), CWT, DAMEN, DeepBV, FMO, MTBS, IHCMerwede,VanOord, STC, PortofAmsterdam, Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU), World Wildlife Fund (WWF).

projects.title: Preperatory Workshop: NWO UDW2 Sustainable Port Development in an African Context
projects.description:
In preperation of the NWO call for tenders the project team went to Tema and Accra, Ghana for a preperatory workshop to gain a deeper understanding of the local situation.

The aim of this project is to develop a framework and tools for designing integrated and sustainable ports in Africa in which environmental, economic and public benefits are balanced. The project incorporates an integrated approach to port design that is stakeholder-inclusive and encompasses engineering, ecological, economic and governance aspects. A bottom-up approach is employed, whereby research in all four disciplines is directed at relevant and practical cases in Africa. Academia, applied research and knowledge institutes, practitioners and potential users collaborate as partners in this project; this is invaluable for ‘action-based’ research and ‘demand driven’ knowledge development. 

Additional deliverables of the project are ‘Best practice guidelines for implementing integrated and sustainable port development in Africa’ and an international 'Green ports Africa network', a community of researchers and private sector practitioners.

Partners: Technical University Delft (TuDelft), Wageningen University (WUR), IMARES, University of Ghana, UNESCO-IHE, Netherlands-African Business Council (NABC), Boskalis, Deltares, Ghana Netherlands Business and Culture Council (GNBCC), CWT, DAMEN, DeepBV, FMO, MTBS, IHCMerwede, VanOord, STC, PortofAmsterdam, Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU), World Wildlife Fund (WWF).

projects.title: MFS II - Incoming Trade Mission Horticulture Q2 - Rwanda
projects.description:
14-19 June 2015 we welcome an incoming delegation from Rwanda which focuses on opportunities in the horticulture sector and partnerships with Dutch counterparts. Both the Dutch and Rwandan horticulture sector are invited to join Seminar, Company Visits and Matchmaking sessions in the Netherlands.

Partners: EKN Kigali, SPARK, GreenPort Holland, VDS-Acampo, USAID, RDB, SMART companies and 18 potential business partners form Rwanda.

projects.title: Incoming Trade Mission - GCCI Ghana - Construction, Garments, Agri-Bussiness (Q1)
projects.description:
NABC and FME will be welcoming an incoming multi-sectoral delegation from Ghana between the 8 and 13 of February as contracted by RVO. We will be hosting 23 GCCI members from various sectors (construction, Agri-business) looking to purchase products, materials, equipment and who want to gain sector knowledge. 

On Tuesday 10 February, 14 companies from the vegetable sector will be present at the Tuinbouw Relatiedagen. During this day there will be an informational seminar followed by a matchmaking session with the Ghanaian companies. Register via www.nabc.nl.

projects.title: Africa Works! 2016
projects.description:
The objective of Africa Works! 2016 is to explore the challenges and opportunities Africa poses to companies, government bodies, NGO’s and knowledge centers through informing, inspiring, and expanding professional networks.

During Africa Works! 2014 we will be focusing on knowledge and practical knowledge questions about the current situation and realities in African countries and what this implies for business, diplomacy, and partnerships when it comes to opportunities and constraints.

Africa Works! is a platform for new partnerships, while ensuring interaction between the above mentioned parties. A combination of scientific seminars and practical workshops will highlight the theme: 'Innovation in Finance'.

contributors.headline: Relatiebeheerder Goede Doelen bij Nationale Postcode Loterij
Master Student WUR - International Development Studies
Business Development, Investment Promotion and Strategic Communication in Africa

projects.title: MFS II - Assesment Week Rwanda/Burundi (Q1)
projects.description: NABC visited Rwanda and Burundi from 16-21 February. As part of the United Entrepreneurship Coalition, coordinated by SPARK, NABC talked to our local partners Rwanda Development Board and the Burundi Chamber of Commerce to intensify our cooperation and plan the activities for 2015. Next to this NABC assessed opportunities for the Dutch private sector in the Rwandan and Burundian livestock and horticulture sector. If you want to know more about our activities in Rwanda and Burundi talk to Heleen Keijer (heleen.keijer@nabc.nl) and if you want to know more about the livestock and horticulture sector in these countries contact Lars Kramer (lars.kramer@nabc.nl).

During Africa Works! 2014 we will be focusing on knowledge and practical knowledge questions about the current situation and realities in African countries and what this implies for business, diplomacy, and partnerships when it comes to opportunities and constraints.

projects.title: Africa Incubator: Renewables @ TNO
projects.description:
On the 12 of June, 2014 NABC will organise a round table on private sector opportunities in the African Renewables Sector.
Tasks: Operational coordination, Sponsor Acquisition, Financial Managment, Content
Results: We brought together a diverse group of people from the renewables sector and as of now we are looking into follow-up activities with regards to a broader program to promote the Dutch renewable sector in Africa.

projects.title: Port & Logistics Trade Mission to Ghana 24-17 september 2013
projects.description:
Tasks: Local seminar/port visit coordination, coordination of matchmaking activities with local 
authorities, participant contact, operational coordination in cooperation with the Dutch Embassy in Accra, Ghana.
Results: The mission participants made use of the many local networking possibilities, while getting to know Ghana as a potential location for FDI and trade. Working together with the Dutch marines proved to be beneficial to both parties.

contributors.headline: Relatiebeheerder Goede Doelen bij Nationale Postcode Loterij
Program Manager Climate Adaptation | Sr. Strategic Advisor | MSc, MA

projects.title: Coordination of the international conference: Africa Works! 21st Century Trends 29-30 October 2012
projects.description:
Tasks: Marketing, participant contact, financial coordination, seminar sales & coordination, sponsor acquisition and funding, speaker acquisition, operational coordination
Results: We met our target of receiving more than 600 individual participants from the private sector (60%), NGO's and knowledgeinstititutes (30%), and government bodies (20%). We empowered the positive discussion on doing business in Africa.

projects.title: The Dutch magazine "Het Nieuwe Afrika"
projects.description:
A joint effort by NABC, ASC  and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs for the general promotion of doing business in Africa. 180.000 magazines were distributed via "het financiele dagblad" in the Netherlands.
Tasks: Co-Editing, design, sponsor and writer acquisition.
Results: Africa has again been positively put on the map, reinforcing the positive discussion on Africa.
